title: Woman 'almost infertile after contraceptive pill left her with 16cm tumour'
text:

A young woman claims she was almost left infertile after her contraceptive pill created a 16cm tumour in her liver.

Tasha Luck started to take contraceptive pills when she was 15-years-old to help with her painful periods, continuing to do so for the next 10 years.

At the beginning she would pop her pills for several weeks at a time before taking a seven-day break in between.

In 2014 she read 'new and unlicensed' research which suggested she could take her medication for a full month without having an induced period.

Four years later, in November 2018, Tasha started to feel physically exhausted, leading her doctor to book her in for a routine blood test.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

The results showed that she had abnormal liver function and, following ultrasounds and CT scans, the bakery assistant was diagnosed with a massive 16cm long tumour growing inside her liver.

In January 2019 her tumour appeared to start shrink after Tasha stopped taking her contraception.

It wasn't enough to stop her needing a grueling five-hour long surgery to remove the massive growth and half of her liver.

Despite doctors worrying the tumour would leave her unable carry a child, they are now confident that Tasha and her husband, Lydon, 30, will be able to start a family next year.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

Tasha told of how she decided to come off the pill after scans showed she had a tumour in her body.

"Due to the size of the tumour there was a chance of a rupture at any time, so I came off the pill, as the doctors were certain this is what caused it, in hopes that it would shrink my tumour - which it did - but not enough for them to operate," she said.

"Luckily, I was able to have the surgery last month, September 25, as I told the hospital I wanted to start a family as soon as possible and the tumour was getting in the way.

"The surgery removed over half of my liver - it was mostly tumour, but some healthy liver was also removed - and now I am waiting for my scar to heal properly."

(Image: Caters News Agency)

Despite the tumour not being cancerous, doctors told Tasha she would not be able to carry a child if the tumour remained inside her.

She said: "I would be able to conceive but not carry the baby whilst the tumour was in there as the baby would push on it as it grew and it would rupture.

"Also the pregnancy hormones would begin to feed the tumour so it would start to grow again.

"I cannot start a family for at least a year due to the location of the scar, but in a way I was 'lucky' that it was my liver, as it will be busy regenerating and should be fully regrown in six months.

"I am scheduled for another scan to confirm it has gone, but my surgeon seemed quite confident he had managed to remove it all.

"For me, it's important to share my story because a lot of people know the common side effects of taking the pill but not the massive dangers it can have."

(Image: Caters News Agency)

According to the Cancer Council , women who take the Pill have a slightly higher risk of breast cancer, but it is usually smaller and easier to treat than in its typical form.

The organisation also notes that daily contraceptives can reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

Cancer Research UK states the risk of contracting these cancers reduces within ten years of a woman stopping taking the pill.
description: Tasha Luck believes the huge tumour that grew on her liver is linked to her use of the contraceptive pill
